intro: Quercus calophylla, commonly known as the California black oak, is a deciduous tree native to the western United States. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its dark, deeply fissured bark and elliptical, glossy leaves. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. Quercus calophylla typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to Mediterranean climates with dry summers and wet winters. Its ecological significance is notable in supporting biodiversity within its native range.
